page.title: 05Pitgaveny in Bourtie
page.content: Pitgaveny hill in bourtie stands, at 773 feet, the highest point of land in the parish, visible 20 miles away from the outskirts of Aberdeen. On occasion it has been named Lawel Hill by mapmakers, and there is a farm on its south side which still oes y the name of Lowhillside, but its original derivation is Pictish, pict-goval-ny, meaning the settlement of the high priest of the Picts. No official archaelogical excavation has ever been carried out here, but in dry summers the crop marks of the foundations of two settlements can be clearly seen on the north slope of Pitgaveny. Flint tools are regular finds. Hillfarm subsides are provided for the farmers who use the top of the hill of sheep grazing, but the lower slopes provide excellent soil for crops of silage winter barley.
